OXBAR(1) General Commands Manual OXBAR(1)

NAME

oxbar —
configurable X11 status bar for OpenBSD

SYNOPSIS

oxbar [
-H
] [
-F config-file
] [
-x xloc
] [
-y yloc
] [
-w width
] [
-h height
] [

] [

] [

] [
-s spacing
] [
-c header-style
] [
-t time-format
] [
-W widgets
] [
-S key=value
] [
theme
]

DESCRIPTION

oxbar is a X11 status bar for OpenBSD showing various system stats. oxbar aims to have a configurable display and work out-of-the-box on most modern window managers in an intuitive fashion. It supports full FreeType font rendering and styling (easily), true transparency/alpha blending on all UI components, and a simple configuration format that can concisely support multiple themes.
oxbar is also a replacement for my old xstatbar(1), and it started as a derivative of that.

Overview of Configuring oxbar

All configurable properties in oxbar can be set via the command line or a configuration file. The default configuration file is $HOME/.oxbar.conf but that can be overridden with the -F config-file command line option. When using a configuration file, the file can be reread at runtime by sending a SIGHUP signal to oxbar.
The configuration file can have any number of named subsections called “themes” that can be loaded on the command line with the theme parameter. See the section FILES below for details on the configuration file format and how to use themes.
Setting configurable properties is always of the form property=value, either from the command line or configuration file. Many properties have intuitive shortcuts on the command line. See the section CONFIGURATION for a list of all configurable properties.

Command Line Flags

oxbar supports the following command line flags, which are backwards compatible with xstatar(1):
-H
Print brief help information regarding the supported command line flags.
-F config-file
Load config-file instead of the default configuration file $HOME/.oxbar.conf.
-x xloc
Sets the x coordinate, in pixels, of the upper-left corner of the window.
Corresponding configurable property: window.x.
-y yloc
Sets the y coordinate, in pixels, of the upper-left corner of the window. If set to -1, the window will be aligned to the bottom of the display minus whatever the height of the window is determined to be.
Corresponding configurable property: window.y.
-w width
Sets the width, in pixels, of the window. If set to -1, the window will span the full width of the X display.
Corresponding configurable property: window.w.
-h height
Sets the height, in pixels, of the window. If set to -1, the window's height will be derived from the font description used and any margins/paddings specified.
Corresponding configurable property: window.h.
-f font
A string specifying the font, and its styling, used throughout the display of oxbar. This supports a very flexible format as it's parsed by pango_font_description_from_string(3). See the section SPECIFYING FONTS below for details on the format and samples.
Corresponding configurable property: font.desc.
-m margins
Sets the margins, in pixels, surrounding each widget shown in oxbar. The margins are the same for every widget. The margins can be specified for the top, right, bottom, and left regions around a widget, in that order, by providing a quoted string with four unsigned integers. E.g. -m “10 20 10 20” would set the top and bottom margins to 10 pixels, and the right and left margins to 20 pixels. Providing a single number, such as -m 10 will set all components to 10 pixels. This follows CSS style conventions.
Corresponding configurable property: gui.margin.
-p paddings
Sets the paddings, in pixels, within each widget shown in oxbar. The paddings are the same for every widget, and can be specified using the same format as the -m margins option (above).
Corresponding configurable property: gui.padding.
-s spacing
Sets the spacing, in pixels, between each widget in the display.
Corresponding configurable property: gui.widget_spacing.
-c header-style
oxbar can show colored “headers” above/below each widget, within the padding region of each widget. These help quickly find/identify widgets visually. The color can be specified per-widget. This option instructs if/where to render such headers. It accepts the following string options:
none
Do not render any header bars.
above
Render header bars in the top padding region of each widget (they will be as wide as the top padding of each widget).
below
Render header bars in the bottom padding region of each widget.
Corresponding configurable property: gui.header_style.
-t time-format
Sets the format used by the time widget when rendering the date/time. This is any string accepted by strftime(3).
Corresponding configurable property: time.format.
-W widgets
A string specifying the list of widgets to be rendered by oxbar and where they should appear. See the section SPECIFYING WIDGETS below on the format of this string.
Corresponding configurable property: widgets.
-S “property=value”
Set any configurable property to value in oxbar. This is a generic way to set any aspect of oxbar at the command line. Note that all such options could also be set in the oxbar configuration file. This option is useful for testing changes/tweaks to oxbar. See the section CONFIGURATION below for a list of all such properties that can be set.
As an example, the flag -S “window.x = 100” would set the x location (in pixels) of the upper-left corner of the display to x. This would be equivalent to either -x 100 at the command line, or a line like window.x = 100 in the configuration file.
theme
An optional theme name to load from the configuration file. If no configuration file is found (either specified via -F config-file or using the default $HOME/.oxbar.conf) an error is returned. When a theme is specified, any lines in the configuration file after a line like [theme] will be loaded. Note theme sections end whenever a new theme is defined. See the FILES section for full details.

ENVIRONMENT

HOME
The user's home directory, which oxbar will use to construct the name of the default configuration file to load if no -F config-file command-line parameter is set. In that case, oxbar will always attempt to load $HOME/.oxbar.conf.

FILES

oxbar can optionally use a configuration file, whose format is described here. When using a configuration file, the file can be re-loaded and processed at runtime by sending a SIGHUP signal to oxbar.

Configuration File Location

By default oxbar will attempt to use $HOME/.oxbar.conf by using the $HOME environment variable. If that variable is not set, getpwuid(3) is used to try and determine the caller's home directory as a replacement for $HOME. If both of those fail, no default configuration file is loaded.
To load a different configuration file on startup, use the -F config-file command line flag.

Configuration File Format

The bulk of the configuration file contains lines like 
property = value
Most properties have a prefix (or “namespace”) that denote the scope of the property. As an example, a line like 
window.x = 100
would set the location of the main window's top-left corner to x (in pixels). And a block like 
window.bgcolor = "ff0000" 
time.bgcolor   = "00ff00"
would set the window's primary background color to red, but the background color for the time widget to green (these are using 32-bit hex color codes, see the section SPECIFYING COLORS for details).
The configuration file is parsed with fparseln(3), and thus supports rich spacing and comments. Specifically,
  • Blank lines are ignored
  • Spacing within lines is liberal. All of the following are permitted and equivalent: 
    window.x=100 
window.x    =     100 
      window.x    =     100
  • Lines can be continued with a \ ending a line, such as: 
    window.x = \ 
           10
  • Anything after a # is considered a comment. 
    # this is a comment 
   # so is this 
window.x = 100    # set offset to 100 (this is a comment)

Using Themes

Themes provide a way to support multiple configurations of oxbar in a single file and load each optionally at runtime. This is useful if you run multiple instances of oxbar, say one configuration for the top of your display showing some widgets, and another configuration at the bottom of your display showing a different set of widgets.
The following example configuration file is used below to discuss the semantics of themes. 
# global configuration 
font.desc = "DejaVu Sans Mono 20px"    # needs DejaVu fonts installed 
font.fgcolor = "93a1a1"                # a light grey 
window.x = 0                           # make oxbar align to left-most pixel 
window.w = -1                          # make oxbar use full width of display 
window.h = -1                          # derive height 
 
[top] 
widgets = "< nprocs cpuslong | memory > net" 
window.y = 0                           # show oxbar at the top of the display 
 
[bottom] 
widgets = "< volume | time > battery" 
window.y = -1                          # show oxbar at the bottom of the display
TODO

CONFIGURATION

This is a complete list of all configurable properties supported by oxbar. They can be set:
  • At the command line with -S property=value, where property is one of the properties listed below and value is the value you which to set it to, or
  • In the configuration file with a line like property=value. See the section FILES for more details on that format.

Useful Terminology

Many of the configurable properties have common suffixes, and knowing what they mean can help to understand their use. These suffixes are:
fgcolor
A foreground color, typically for text.
bgcolor
A background color, for the whole window or individual widgets.
hdcolor
A header color, typically denoting the header of each widget (the horizontal bars optionally shown above or below each widget). These properties allow you to color each widget's bar seperately.
pgcolor
The color of a progress indicator, typically a progress bar (like those used for the battery and volume widgets).

Font Properties

font.desc
Set's the font and styles to be used throughout the display.
Default value: “helvetica 16px”
font.fgcolor
Set's the default foreground color for all text in the display. Note the foreground color of each widget can be overriden (see other options below).
Default value: “#93a1a1”

SEE ALSO

https://xcb.freedesktop.org
XCB is a MIT licensed X rendering library used by oxbar to connect to an X display, render the window, and handle events.
https://www.pango.org
Pango is a LGPL licensed text layout / font rendering engine used by oxbar to load, render, and style fonts. Pango supports most modern fonts and font features.
https://cairographics.org
Cairo is a LGPL licensed vector graphics rendering library used by oxbar for all graphics rendering.

STANDARDS

oxbar is written natively on OpenBSD. It adheres to a strict C89 standard on the base clang(1) compiler, and builds/runs cleanly with “-std=c89 -Wall -Wextra -Werror”. Additionally, the make(1) targets scan-build and cppcheck run those tools, respecitively, and should remain error/warning-free.
style(9) is mostly followed, but there's still work there to be done.
If interested in contributing, see the following link for tips on navigating the code base and getting started adding stats, widgets, etc:
https://github.com/ryanflannery/oxbar/CONTRIBUTING.md
The github repo is the place to submit bugs/changes/threats, and is located at: https://github.com/ryanflannery/oxbar

HISTORY

oxbar started as xstatbar, first written in 2006 as a status-bar that would work reasonably well for OpenBSD. It was written on a Friday and Saturday evening and had many, many bugs/shortcomings/etc. It was further hacked over a few years to support a handful of new features and widgets, but the term “hacked” there undervalues the level of code shit-hattery done to “Make-It-Work!”. I have personally received much derision because of that, and oxbar is an attempt to eliminate that.
Shaming works 'yo.

AUTHORS

oxbar is written and maintained by Ryan Flannery <ryan.flannery@gmail.com> or https://ryanflannery.net.
